image.altText: A road leading into a town camp within Alice Springs, on a sunny day.

props.synopsis: There are fears a lack of communication around the Alice Springs youth curfew could lead to children being punished by police, after multiple residents told the ABC they were unaware of the declaration.

title.children: Alice Springs residents unaware of youth curfew as government's communication criticised

props.synopsis: Ruby was told she had a 75 per cent chance of dying if she kept riding bulls. She liked those odds.

title.children: This 13-year-old can't kick her bull-riding obsession — even after four brain bleeds

image.altText: Four wheel driving enthusiasts driving down a muddy track in southern Tasmania

props.synopsis: The Albanese government says it wants more EVs in Australia and wants to provide more "choice" to Australians in the hope they will choose EVs themselves. But how likely is that?

title.children: Australians love big, fuel-hungry utes. What does that mean for the future of EVs — and Australia's climate ambitions?

image.altText: a young man and woman sit on a log wearing hats in a green forest.

props.synopsis: As tensions rise between China and Taiwan, young people on the island say there are lots more things on their minds than just the thought of war.

title.children: How much does war with China scare Taiwan's youth?

image.altText: A close-up of a sheep standing in a paddock

props.synopsis: The humble sheep might be considered by some as the perfect embodiment of docility. But they are not mundane mindless mammals — not in the slightest.

title.children: Sheep are 'much cannier' than we give them credit for. These ovine facts may surprise you

image.altText: Nicole and Brenda

props.synopsis: The Key Bridge was considered so iconic at the Key Brewery, a nearby namesake, that a big TV beamed a live shot into the bar. Now, the screen displays an empty vista of sky and clouds.

title.children: 'Not just a bridge': What happens to a city when it loses an icon?

image.altText: Human eye, seen as if in an hallucinogenic episode.

props.synopsis: There is no cure for HPPD. The condition, triggered by the use of psychedelic drugs, has been described by sufferers as the "trip that never ends".

title.children: 'Some people reckon it's cool to be tripping every day, but it's terrible': The 'nightmare' of HPPD

image.altText: Lady sitting at a desk on her laptop with a view overlooking a lake

props.synopsis: If you've ever wanted to do your desk job from an exotic location, becoming a digital nomad visa could be for you. Here's what you need to know.

title.children: Dreaming of working remotely from an idyllic location? Here are the countries that offer digital nomad visas

image.altText: A shocked-looking woman with dark curly hair holds a laptop in one hand, a phone to her ear in the other

props.synopsis: Let me tell you a sobering and instructive story of how youthful curiosity and low-level larceny can be terribly bad for your financial health. This could be life or death info.

title.children: Was it the husband? Porn? A sobering story of mysterious credit card charges and a dreaded question

image.altText: woman smiling wearing t-shirt in building with balloons background

props.synopsis: Rosanna Natoli has won the race to lead one of Queensland's largest councils, and will serve alongside her husband Joe Natoli who has been re-elected as a councillor.

title.children: TV presenter declared Sunshine Coast mayor

image.altText: Scenes from a shooting incident in Cairns Botanic Gardens

props.synopsis: Queensland police find two of the three people involved in an incident that saw a gunshot fired and an emergency declaration enforced.

title.children: Man in hospital with gunshot wound after Cairns car crash

image.altText: A woman leans against the wall of a boat shed.

props.synopsis: Nikki Ayers wanted to play for the Australian women's rugby union team, but when a serious knee injury, and multiple surgeries ended that career, she switched to para-rowing, and is now the world's best.

title.children: 'Dreams never die': Nikki Ayers embraces gold medal favouritism for Paralympics

image.altText: Imogen Mulgrew tosses the coin for Jy Simpkin and Patrick Cripps

props.synopsis: Fremantle prevail over the winless Crows in the west, after Carlton make light work of North Melbourne in their Good Friday fixture at Docklands.

title.children: Heartwarming coin toss moment steals the show as Blues down Roos, Dockers beat struggling Crows

image.altText: Seen from behind, Cowboys' Tom Dearden makes a diving tackle on Selwyn Cobbo of the Broncos.

props.synopsis: North Queensland half Tom Dearden pulls off a stunning try-saving tackle to deny Selwyn Cobbo early in the second half in Brisbane, but coach Todd Payten says his team's reaction, or lack thereof, was the worst part of a bad night for the Cowboys.

title.children: How Tom Dearden's miracle try-saver turned into 'the most disappointing part' of the Cowboys' thrashing by Brisbane

image.altText: Former AFL player Eddie Betts stands in a suit on stage in front of a microphone during an awards ceremony.

props.synopsis: Police confirm they have received a report into racial abuse, after Eddie Betts posted security footage of his kids being yelled at from a car in Melbourne.

title.children: Police investigating after Eddie Betts posts security footage of his kids being racially abused in their yard

image.altText: Richard Marles in a suit with yellow tie shakes hands with a man with grey hair dressed in a suit.

props.synopsis: South Korea's new ambassador to Australia has resigned after less than a month in the job, as he faces a corruption probe at home.

title.children: South Korea's ambassador to Australia resigns after less than a month in the job

image.altText: Three police officers stand in a line guarding a street as protesters linger nearby.

props.synopsis: Radio Free Asia says comments by Hong Kong authorities referring to it as a "foreign force" has led to its decision.

title.children: Radio station closes Hong Kong bureau after passing of new security law

image.altText: A graphic showing magpies in the shape of a question mark.

props.synopsis: For more than 120 years, a question involving magpies has endlessly ruffled feathers — why is the bird on South Australia's state flag called a piping shrike? Trying to come up with an answer can feel like a wild goose chase, but ornithologists insist there's a simple solution.

title.children: Magpies, magpie-larks and the striking mystery of the piping shrike

image.altText: A woman with long blonde hair smiling with teeth in front of a colourful painted outside exterior wall.

props.synopsis:
Whatever your motivation, re-examining your approach buying clothes can be good for your budget and the planet.

We spoke with a stylist, a sustainability advocate and a designer, to get some tips on how to maintain your personal style while being environmentally conscious.

title.children: Wear your beautiful thing today: Sustainable shopping doesn't mean a boring wardrobe

image.altText: An elderly man with a button-up shirt with flowers stares at the camera.

props.synopsis: The Organ and Tissue Authority (OTA) has released data for organ donation rates in Australia last year. While there was improvement in the number of transplants, the consent rate by families rose by only one per cent and donor registrations have plummeted.

title.children: Transplant recipients say organ donation rates in Australia 'are pretty bad'

image.altText: Eartha Kitt performs at Cafe Carlyle in New York City

props.synopsis: Long before Leonardo DiCaprio lent his voice to environmental causes in Tasmania, legendary American musician and actress Eartha Kitt joined the fray — and it wasn't the only cause close to her heart in Australia.

title.children: Blacklisted for speaking out at home, Eartha Kitt campaigned on Australian causes

image.altText: Jake looks down slightly with a serious expression, his shirt open over his bare chest and cuts and blood on his face.

props.synopsis: It's the Easter long weekend so that obviously means chocolate and TV. Here's a rundown of the best new shows and movies streaming right now.

title.children: What to watch this Easter, from the thirsty new Gyllenhaal flick to sci-fi thriller 3 Body problem

image.altText: A collection of book covers on a green background

props.synopsis: Our favourite new reads include pacy crime fiction from one of Australia's top journalists, a timely reimagining of an American masterpiece and an examination of gender by a ground-breaking philosopher.

title.children: Heartbreaking, utterly hilarious and crammed with ideas: The best books to read this month

image.altText: Mr Karagania is holding a packet of fish, standing in a fish market.

props.synopsis: From "blessed" church gatherings, to a family picnic and Easter egg hunt, and seafood-focused feasts — here's how locals are marking Good Friday.

title.children: How Australia is spending Good Friday

image.altText: D'Arenberg chief winemaker Chester Osborn.

props.synopsis: While wine authorities say getting Australian exports to China back to pre-tariff levels could be "a matter of years", many in the industry are not only rejoicing, but getting set to resume shipments.

title.children: 'Great Friday' for winemakers ready to 'instantly' resume shipments of China-bound drops

image.altText: A photo of a man holding a phone displaying whatsapp messages.

props.synopsis: When Paul called ING with a question about his cryptocurrency investment, the bank's scam team was alerted. Now, after losing nearly $500,000 to a romance scam, Paul argues the bank could have stopped it.

title.children: Dianna messaged Paul out of the blue. What looked like happiness cost him nearly $500k

image.altText: Louis Gossett Jr poses for a photo.

props.synopsis: The acclaimed actor received the Academy Award for best actor in 1983 for his performance in An Officer and a Gentleman, becoming the first Black man to win the award.

title.children: Louis Gossett Jr, first Black man to win supporting actor Oscar, dies at 87

image.altText: A man wearing a crown of thorns and a white robe around his waist nailed to a cross. Two people to his side are tied to a cross.

props.synopsis: One Filipino Catholic was nailed to a cross for the 35th time on Good Friday, while rain in Spain dampened spirits.

title.children: From crucifixions to torrential rain, this is how the world marked Good Friday

image.altText: Palestinian children in a queue holding saucepans

props.synopsis: The World Court has ordered Israel to "take all necessary and effective" action to ensure access to food and medical supplies for Gaza's Palestinian population in an effort to improve the humanitarian situation.

title.children: 'Famine is setting in': World Court orders Israel to open more land crossings to allow aid into Gaza

image.altText: People stand outside the Aleppo International Airport in Syria

props.synopsis: Stepping up its campaign against Iran's proxies in parallel with its war in Gaza, Israel carries out strikes on northern Syria's Aleppo province early and kills a senior Hezbollah commander in Lebanon.

title.children: Israel hits Syria in heaviest raid on Iran proxies in months

image.altText: An SA Police vehicle with flashing lights.

props.synopsis: A police officer is airlifted to hospital in Adelaide after being hit by a car that then allegedly left the scene on South Australia's Barrier Highway, according to the state's police force.

title.children: Victorian man arrested after police officer hit by car in SA's mid-north

image.altText: Steve Martin looks slightly to the right as he sits at a table with his arms crossed in front of him, a pensive look on his face

props.synopsis: Morgan Neville's poignant documentary explores the cultural phenomenon that is Steve Martin.

title.children: New doco exploring the life of comedy legend Steve Martin will have you in your feelings

image.altText: A Black man shovels a pile of dried cocoa beans from a wooden box.

props.synopsis: Over the last few years, a peculiar change has taken place in Papua New Guinea's north-west, with remote, traditional villages modernising at a rapid pace. Here's how the price of cocoa is fuelling development.

title.children: Inside this brightly coloured pod is white slimy gold. Tiny PNG villages are cashing in
